moves.3. Nf3 Bc5: and here we're done with my knowledge of theory
moves.4. d4 Bb6 5. Bxf4 d5: White hunts the bishop and enables itself to retake the pawn on f4 (I'm pretty sure this has some name, I think I've seen this quite often).
moves.6. Nc3 Bg4: Black decides to pin White's Knight and leaves the Pawn on D5 defended only by the Queen... so White decides to take it
moves.7. exd5 Ba5 8. Bb5+: Now Black tries to pin the knight, such that the Queen can retake the pawn. White counters by a check on B5.
moves.8... c6: The other option I saw for black was Nd7, which would also have saved the pawn
moves.9. dxc6 bxc6 10. Ba4 Bxc3+ 11. bxc3: Black gives away the pair of bishops.
moves.11... Qa5 12. Qe2+: White tries to build up some pressure
moves.12... Ne7 13. Bd6: White builds up some pressure (mate on Qxe7) and wants to snatch of the knight
moves.13... O-O 14. Qxe7 Na6: Black prevents a mate on Qxf8
moves.15. Bxc6:
A big blunder by white, a better option would have been 15. Bb3. Of course it could not have prevented the check on Qc3. I actually thought about castling short for a few moments... don't know why I didn't...
Possible variation would then have been:
15.Bb3 Qxc3+ 16.Kf2 Bxf3 17 xf3 Qxd4+ 18. Kg3 h6 And white would have a naked King, but the pair of Bishops and thereby a piece in advance (although a pawn less)
moves.17... Qxc2+ 18. Kg3 Be6 19. Qb7: Attacking the Knight and the Rook at once
moves.19... Qc3+ 20. Nf3 Qc8: Defending the Knight by a counterattack
moves.21. Qb5 Rd8 22. Rhc1: Starting again a counter attack and slowly starting to move into a bad position
moves.22... Qd7: Up to this point an exchange could have been the startingpoint to an balanced endgame. Although white has an isolated pawn (which would get hard to defend)
moves.23. Rc6 Nb8 24. Ne5: Again: attacking instead of defending, following a tactic, which has in this situation no hope for success
moves.24... Qe8 25. Bxb8 Raxb8 26. Qc5 f6: The next blunder... I thought i Take the Bishop and then I'll have a forkat C6... but this fork is no real fork, sind black can escape while checking...
moves.29. Kg4: This was esspecially bad since it allows Qe2+ and then to save one Rook....
moves.29... Qe2+ 30. Kh3 Rb5: What had to come... white begins to get desperate and takes a pawn... leaving the King defenceless
moves.31. Qxa7 Rh5+ 32. Kg3 Qe3+ 33. Kg4 Rg5+: And I resigned, seeing the mate in one
